item.title: Spain Sets Stage to Take Control of Catalonia in Independence Fight
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont, the leader of Catalonia, has requested mediation over his region’s status in Spain.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: Carles Puigdemont, Catalonia’s leader, said in a letter to the Spanish prime minister that the regional Parliament could vote to break away if Madrid tried to seize administrative control.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Suspecting Russian Meddling in ‘Brexit’ Vote, Lawmaker Seeks Inquiry
item.media:description: Arron Banks was a major supporter of Leave.EU, the unofficial campaign for Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union.
item.description: The former Labour minister, Ben Bradshaw, points to reports that question whether a major donor could have afforded the millions he gave to the campaign.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: This Is What Victory Over ISIS Looks Like
item.media:description: Kobani, Syria, after an invasion by the Islamic State was repelled in 2015.
item.description: Cities in Syria and Iraq have been wrested from the Islamic State at a terrible cost. They are ghosts of their former glory.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Burqa Bans: Which Countries Outlaw Face Coverings?
item.media:description: A protest in Montreal in 2013 against a proposal to outlaw public sector employees from wearing face veils. Quebec passed a face veil ban on Wednesday.
item.description: Austria. France. Part of Canada. More regions are considering or adopting laws that restrict such garments in public.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: The Interpreter: Myanmar, Once a Hope for Democracy, Is Now a Study in How It Fails
item.media:description: Supporters of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi on Oct. 10 in Yangon, Myanmar, at what was billed as an Interreligious Gathering of Prayers for Peace.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Nationalism, an unchecked ethnic majority and support for authoritarian values have put Myanmar well down the road to becoming an “illiberal democracy.”
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: U.S. Works to Keep Palestinians’ Talks on Track to Aid Peace
item.media:description: Saleh al-Aruri of Hamas, seated left, and Azam al-Ahmad of Fatah signing a reconciliation deal in Cairo last week.
item.description: As Egypt works to bring together two rival Palestinian factions, President Trump’s special Middle East envoy visited Cairo to help move those talks along.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Canada Welcomed Refugees, but Now Struggles With Backlog
item.media:description: Asylum seekers at a processing center at the Canadian border in Quebec in August.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Partly because of an influx of asylum seekers crossing the border illegally into Quebec this year, tens of thousands of people are caught in a bureaucratic limbo.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Sevastopol Journal: Crimean Winemakers Look to Shed the Rot Gut Label
item.media:description: The vineyard of the Russian winemaker Pavel Shvets, outside Sevastopol.
item.media:credit: Denis Sinyakov for The New York Times
item.description: Pioneer boutique winemakers around Sevastopol are seeking to convince Russian consumers that quality wine does not have to come from France.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: As ISIS’ Role in Syria Wanes, Other Conflicts Take the Stage
item.media:description: American-backed forces have largely driven the Islamic State from Raqqa, above. The big question is who will rule it next.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: The Syrian war did not begin or end with the Islamic State. Who will control the cities and territories where ISIS was evicted is an open question.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Body Found in Argentine River Shakes Up Election
item.media:description: In August, demonstrators in Buenos Aires held up photographs of Santiago Maldonado, an indigenous rights activist who had been missing for a little over a week at the time.
item.description: The discovery of a body near the site where an indigenous rights activist vanished two months ago has raised questions about the government’s investigation.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: John Kelly, George Bush, Quentin Tarantino: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Xi Jinping, Catalonia, Islamic State: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Key ISIS Operative in Philippines ‘Taken’ in Gunfight, President Says
item.media:description: Soldiers walking past damaged houses in Marawi, a southern city in the Philippines, on Thursday.
item.description: Mahmud Ahmad had acted as a link to the group’s central command in Syria, helping funnel money and foreign fighters who ransacked a city in the south.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Japanese Carmakers Call Kobe Steel’s Products Safe Despite Scandal
item.media:description: The headquarters for Kobe Steel in Tokyo. Positive safety reviews of its products by Toyota, Honda and Mazda could help lift a cloud over the company, which has said its inspectors falsified data.
item.description: A round of positive findings from Toyota, Honda and Mazda could help lift a cloud over the Japanese supplier, which has said its inspectors falsified data.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Food Inequality in Venezuela: Children in Crisis
item.description: Food shortages and the lack of affordable goods has led to growing malnutrition rates in Venezuela. A nonprofit initiative provides community lunches for children in low-income neighborhoods in an attempt to alleviate the problem.

item.title: Afghan Army Unit Nearly Wiped Out as New Taliban Tactic Takes Toll
item.media:description: A checkpoint on a highway leading to Maywand District in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan, on Thursday.
item.description: Forty-three soldiers were killed after militants drove stolen Humvees packed with explosives into an army base, mirroring a tactic used in two recent attacks.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Nawaz Sharif, Ousted Pakistani Leader, Is Indicted in Corruption Case
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan in front of party supporters in Lahore on Oct. 4.
item.description: The charges against the former prime minister stem from his family’s ownership of expensive residential property in London.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: China’s Reform Hopefuls Watch for Names. Only One May Matter.
item.media:description: The cultural hub of Guangzhou, China, is Haixinsha Asian Games Park, popular for strolling and shopping. The park is one of a number of recent projects that have helped give the city and surrounding Guangdong Province a reputation for appealing development.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: A leadership shuffle in the Communist Party could hint at its commitment to an economic overhaul, but Xi Jinping’s growing power may hinder that effort.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Jacinda Ardern, 37, Will Be New Zealand’s Youngest Prime Minister
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern is poised to become the new prime minister of New Zealand.
item.description: A dramatic show of support from a minor party has put Ms. Ardern in line to be the country’s youngest prime minister in more than 150 years.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM

item.title: Europe Edition: Donald Trump, Catalonia, Nxivm: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: China’s Economy Grew Steadily, Thanks to Loans and Homes
item.media:description: Shoppers in Shanghai. Retail spending, housing sales and trade figures suggest an economy growing steadily under the guiding hand of the government.
item.description: China’s economy expanded by 6.8 percent in the third quarter, but an upswing in credit suggests Beijing is still grappling with an addiction to debt.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Letter 30: Live Journalism, with Song, History and Taylor Mac in Melbourne
item.media:description: Taylor Mac bringing the old and young together on stage in Melbourne.
item.description: This week’s newsletter digs into discussion and events with The New York Times in Australia.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Struggle Over Kirkuk Puts the U.S. and Iran on the Same Side
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces in military vehicles in Kirkuk on Tuesday.
item.description: Kurdish and Iraqi forces, both armed by the Americans, fought each other in Kirkuk. Analysts think Iran played a key role in the dispute’s resolution.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Former Trump Hotel Partner Charged in Brazil Olympic Bribery Case
item.media:description: Carlos Nuzman, the president of the Brazilian Olympic Committee, was escorted by federal police officers after being taken into custody at his home, in Rio de Janeiro on Oct. 5.
item.description: Prosecutors in Brazil say a wealthy businessman paid bribes to get the 2016 Games to Rio and was later rewarded through his stake in a would-be Trump hotel.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Kenyan Election Official Fears New Vote Won’t Be Credible
item.media:description: The Kenyan opposition leader, Raila Odinga, right, at a rally in Mombasa on Sunday. Mr. Odinga was defeated in a presidential election in August, but the Supreme Court annulled the results. He said he would withdraw from the new election because its fairness could not be guaranteed.
item.description: The chairman of the electoral commission accused the top political parties of interfering with the election, scheduled for next week.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: Lamar Alexander, Jeff Sessions, Xi Jinping: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Russian Socialite Enters Race to Challenge President Putin
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak speaks to the crowd during opposition protests in Moscow in 2012.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Ksenia Sobchak, a TV journalist who has long paraded her glamorous life on social media, says she will be the voice of Russians without one.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to U.N. Escalates Confrontation With Iran
item.description: The ambassador, Nikki R. Haley, used a Security Council meeting on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to deliver a strident denunciation of Iran’s behavior.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Xi Jinping, Rohingya, Islamic State: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Quebec Bars People in Face Coverings From Receiving Public Services
item.media:description: A Muslim woman waiting for a bus in Quebec City on Wednesday. A law passed in Quebec prohibits people wearing face coverings from using public services.
item.media:credit: Catherine Côté for The New York Times
item.description: Under a new law, women in face veils will not be able to use public transportation or work as public employees, including as teachers.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: From Playground to Killing Ground: An ISIS Legacy
item.media:description: The Naem traffic circle, in 2013 and on Tuesday.
item.description: The Naem traffic circle in Raqqa teemed with life before the Syrian civil war. Then it came to symbolize death.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Guiyang Journal: Forget Marx and Mao. Chinese City Honors Once-Banned Confucian.
item.media:description: The city of Guiyang has led a Chinese revival of interest in Wang Yangming, a 16th-century Confucian scholar, with attractions including a park devoted to him.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Guiyang has built a museum and park to Wang Yangming, a 16th-century philosopher at the center of a propaganda drive by China’s leader, Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Marathon Speech: Five Takeaways
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China delivering a speech at the opening ceremony of the 19th Communist Party congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Wednesday.
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China gave a 205-minute speech to open the Communist Party congress. Here is what mattered.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: U.S. Stood By as Indonesia Killed a Half-Million People, Papers Show
item.media:description: Detained members of a youth wing of Indonesia’s Communist Party in Jakarta in October 1965. Half a million Indonesians or more, many of whom had no connection to communism, were estimated to have been killed during the crackdown.
item.description: The killings in 1965-66 played to anti-Communist attitudes, and U.S. diplomats mostly stayed silent while tallying the deaths, documents show.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Rohingya Refugees Fleeing Myanmar Await Entrance to Squalid Camps
item.media:description: A Bangladeshi border guard stops Rohingya, newly arrived Myanmar, from approaching crowded refugee camps on Tuesday.
item.description: Thousands of Rohingya fleeing violence have crossed the border to Bangladesh, but their journey is far from over.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: In Italian Schools, Reading, Writing and Recognizing Fake News
item.media:description: Laura Boldrini, president of Italy’s Chamber of Deputies, spearheaded a project to educate high-school students on how to recognize fake news and conspiracy theories online.
item.description: A new program, aided by companies like Facebook, will aim to teach students how to recognize and stop the sharing of fake news and conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: News Analysis: With Loss of Its Caliphate, ISIS May Return to Guerrilla Roots
item.media:description: Syrian Democratic Forces fighters in Raqqa this month. The Islamic State may be losing its capital but not its bite.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: With the fall of its capital and loss of territory, the Islamic State may be reeling but not vanquished.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET COKER, ERIC SCHMITT and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Food Inequality in Venezuela: Feeding Eight on Scraps
item.description: Food shortages and rising inflation have made basic groceries unaffordable for many Venezuelans, over 80 percent of whom now live in poverty. After losing her job two years ago, Francia has been feeding her family from the garbage of a supermarket in Caracas.

item.title: Europe Edition: Raqqa, Catalonia, Andrej Babis: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: U.N. Peacekeeping Chief Issues Warning on South Sudan
item.media:description: South Sudanese refugees after crossing into Uganda in June. More than two million people have fled South Sudan and nearly two million have been displaced.
item.description: The under secretary general for peacekeeping exhorted South Sudan’s antagonists to “bring the country back from the impending abyss.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations

item.title: Lawsuit Claims Three U.S. Companies Funded Terror in Iraq
item.media:description: Ami Neiberger-Miller at home. Her brother, Chris Neiberger, was killed in Iraq in 2007.
item.media:credit: Mary F. Calvert for The New York Times
item.description: The lawsuit, filed in federal court in Washington, cited as evidence contracts between the companies and the Iraqi government, leaked diplomatic cables, and the testimony of informants.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Iranian News Media on Trump: ‘He Just Whined’
item.description: President Trump announced that the United States would not recertify Iran’s compliance with the nuclear deal. Here's how Iran’s news media reacted.

item.title: Health Care, Raqqa, N.B.A.: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: ‘Come Out and Surrender’: Inside Raqqa, With the Fighters Who Drove Off ISIS
item.media:description: A fighter with the Syrian Democratic Forces, an American-backed militia group made up of Syrian Kurds and Arabs, walked down an empty street in Raqqa last week.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.description: A New York Times photographer accompanied Kurdish fighters as they entered Raqqa, the Syrian city that had been a stronghold of the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: Photographs and Text by IVOR PRICKETT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: After Drone Hits Plane in Canada, New Fears About Air Safety
item.media:description: Marc Garneau, Canada’s transport minister.
item.description: Pilots are filing reports of drones flying too high on a weekly, almost daily basis, despite new rules and fines.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Navy SEALs Were Ready if Pakistan Failed to Free Family Held as Hostages
item.description: American officials asked Pakistan to rescue an American woman, her Canadian husband and their children. With new intelligence on their whereabouts, officials had limited time to act.
item.dc:creator: ADAM GOLDMAN and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Memo from Lombardy: First Scotland, Then Catalonia. And Now? Milan and Venice
item.media:description: A poster advertising the upcoming referendum on the back of a bus in Milan. Voters in the Northern League-governed regions of Lombardy and Veneto will decide Oct. 22 if they want their presidents to seek greater autonomy.
item.description: Two regions of northern Italy will vote on whether to request greater autonomy. They’re not demanding secession, but the referendums are being closely watched.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
